intro: Pinus uncinata subsp. uncinata, commonly known as the Spanish black pine, is a subspecies native to the Iberian Peninsula. It is a medium-sized evergreen conifer with needle-like leaves that are typically dark green and have a slight upward curve. The cones are woody and can persist on the tree for several years before opening. This species thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is adapted to Mediterranean climates. Its ecological role includes providing habitat for various wildlife species and contributing to forest biodiversity.
